title: Single cause, single effect
text: When the red button is pushed the system shuts down.

graph.desc: In this very explicit case with only one cause and one effect, the CEG consists of exactly two nodes connected by a normal edge.

testsuite.desc: Two test cases are generated based on the cause-effect graph: the positive, explicit case that happens when the cause is true, and the negative, implicit case that happens when the effect is false.

title: Single cause, single negated effect
text: When the green button is pushed the system does not shut down.

graph.desc: If a negation node is contained within an event node, then the edge leading from or to this node is negated (indicated by the dashed line).

title: Single negated cause, single negated effect
text: When the red button is not pushed the system does not shut down.

graph.desc: In this case, both the cause and the effect node in a two-event causality are negated. The two negations cancel each other, hence a regular, positive edge connects the two nodes.

title: Two conjunctive causes, single effect
text: When the red button is pushed and the power fails the system shuts down.

graph.desc: If two causes and a conjunction between them is detected, then the two cause nodes are connected with an intermediate node representing the conjunction. The conjunction represents that both events must be true in order for the effect to occur.

testsuite.desc: For this acceptance test, next to the trivial positive test case two negative test cases are created, one for each cause to be responsible for the conjunction to be evaluated to false. It is unnecessary to also test the fourth possible case, where both causes are evaluated to false, as the existing two negative test cases already verify that each cause can be responsible for evaluating the conjunction to false.

title: Two disjunctive causes, single effect
text: When the red button is pushed or the power fails the system shuts down.

graph.desc: If two causes and a disjunction between them is detected, then the two cause nodes are connected with an intermediate node representing the disjunction. The disjunction represents that at least one event must be true in order for the effect to occur.

testsuite.desc: For this acceptance test, next to the trivial negative test case two positive test cases are created, one for each cause to be responsible for the disjunction to be evaluated to true. It is unnecessary to also test the fourth possible case, where both causes are evaluated to true, as the existing two positive test cases already verify that each cause can be responsible for evaluating the disjunction to true.

title: Three conjunctive causes, single effect
text: If the user is over 18 years old, the current time is during working hours, and the current day is a workday, then the door opens.

graph.desc: In this case, three cause labels are connected by the same conjunction. The conjunction between Cause1 and Cause2 is implicitly assumed as the connective phrase is usually omitted in natural language.

title: Three disjunctive causes, single effect
text: If the user is over 18 years old, the current time is during working hours, or the current day is a workday, then the door opens.

graph.desc: In this case, three cause labels are connected by the same disjunction. The disjunction between Cause1 and Cause2 is implicitly assumed as the connective phrase is usually omitted in natural language.

title: Three causes (conjunction + disjunction), single effect
text: If var1 is present and var2 is active or var3 is triggered then var4 will be caused.

graph.desc: In a case, where three causes are connected by both conjunctions and disjunctions, they are interpreted as logical ANDs and ORs, where the logical AND has a higher precedence than the logical OR. Hence, the logical AND is binding stronger.

testsuite.desc: For each of the two possible expected results (the effect being evaluated to true and to false), the relevant number of test cases is generated: in the positive case, the final causal node (in this case the final intermediate node representing the disjunction with an OR) has to be evaluated to true. Evaluating a disjunction to true entails creating one test case for each node contained in the disjunction to true, while the others are false. Hence, one test case is created where the intermediate node representing the conjunction with an AND is evaluated to true and the 'var3'' node to false - and the other way around. The test case creation rules are then cascaded for the second test case, where the 'var3' node is evaluated to true and consequently the conjunction is evaluated to false, for which again two distinct options exist. Therefore, three positive test cases are created.

title: Three causes (conjunction + disjunction), two effects
text: If var1 is present and var2 is active or var3 is triggered then var4 will be caused and var5 will not be caused.

graph.desc: In a case, where three causes are connected by both conjunctions and disjunctions, they are interpreted as logical ANDs and ORs, where the logical AND has a higher precedence than the logical OR. Hence, the logical AND is binding stronger.

title: Three causes (conjunction + disjunction), single effect
text: If var1 is present or var2 is active and var3 is triggered then var4 will be caused.

graph.desc: Despite the disjunction ('or') appearing before the conjunction ('and'), the conjunction has a higher precedence similar to logics. Hence, Cause2 and Cause3 are more strongly connected than Cause1 and Cause2.

title: Single cause, two effects
text: When the red button is pushed the system shuts down and energy is saved.

title: Two conjunctive, exceptive causes, single effect
text: Unless the red button is pushed and the power fails the system continues to operate.

title: Three exceptive causes (conjunction + disjunction), single effect
text: Unless the director gives the orders and the red button is pressed or the power fails then the system remains active.

title: Two disjunctive causes, two effects
text: When the red button is pushed or the power fails the interface does not accept further inputs and the system shuts down.

title: Three conjunctive causes, two effects
text: If the user is over 18 years old, the door is currently not blocked, and no defect could be detected, then the door opens and welcoming music is played.

title: Three disjunctive causes with implicit variables, two effects with implicit conditions
text: Where it is impractical to substantially eliminate or reduce the hazard or where the condition of the hazard indicates additional emphasis, special operating procedures and training will be used.

title: Single cause in relative clause, single effect
text: Users which are older than 18 years, are allowed to drive.

title: Three causes (conjunction + disjunction) with overruled precedence, single effect
text: When the applicant can present an identity card and either is not underage or can present a parent's permission, then an account can be opened with the bank.

nodes.condition: can be opened with the bank

expected.condition: can be opened with the bank
